title: Confusing error involving lifetime elision

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: D-confusing
labels.description: Confusing diagnostic error that should be reworked

labels.name: D-incorrect
labels.description: A diagnostic that is giving misleading or incorrect information

body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.
-->

The following code:

```rust
struct A<'a> {
    backref: Option<&'a mut A<'a>>,
    value: String,
}

impl<'a> A<'a> {
    fn child_with_value(&'a mut self, value: String) -> A<'a> {
        A {
            backref: Some(self),
            value,
        }
    }
}

fn works(a: &mut A) {
    println!("{}", a.value);
}

fn errors(a: &mut A) {
    let mut b = a.child_with_value("foo".into());
    errors(&mut b);
}
```
Gives this error:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/14111053/101712550-0f3b9300-3a96-11eb-8791-71f2bf20bf6a.png)


I expected to see this happen:  
Given that the invocation should be legal, I expect this to compile without issues :)

Instead, this happened: Compiler error above. Note that the variable flows into itself, which seems strange

### Meta
<!--
If you're using the stable version of the compiler, you should also check if the
bug also exists in the beta or nightly versions.
-->

Tested both on stable and nightly:
`rustc --version --verbose`:
```
rustc 1.50.0-nightly (f0f68778f 2020-12-09)
binary: rustc
commit-hash: f0f68778f798d6d34649745b41770829b17ba5b8
commit-date: 2020-12-09
host: x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu
release: 1.50.0-nightly
```

Backtrace not applicable I think?
